International Workshop on: MATHEMATICAL METHODS AND MODELS IN LASER FILAMENTATION

Location: Montreal, Canada

Dates. December 9-13th 2013, from Monday AM to Friday Noon.

Web Address: http://www.crm.umontreal.ca/cal/en/liste.shtml#2008-2009-autres

The proposed international workshop on "Mathematical Methods and Models in Laser Filamentation" aims to bring leading experts from within the multi-disciplinary fields of applied mathematics, experimental and theoretical laser physics together in a forum which aims to identify new opportunities and challenges facing the mathematics community in particular in elucidating new mathematical tools that address the emerging field of extreme nonlinear optics. Specific topics to be addressed will include the development of asymptotic approaches to derive mathematical reductions of optical carrier resolved few-cycle laser pulse propagation models that describe singular blow-up and optical carrier shocks under such extreme conditions, quantum based light-matter regularization mechanisms, novel numerical analysis tools and the development of new computational approaches to solving the resultant integro differential equation models that result from such asymptotic reductions. Specific plans to disseminate the outcome of the workshop include publication of extended chapters on the plenary lectures in a book, advertise the workshop online with registration information for students /postdocs and post online links to lectures after the workshop.

Filamentation science covers a broad swath of emerging scientific endeavors that relate to the interaction of very intense, ultra-short duration laser light pulses with gaseous and solid materials. Femtosecond pulse propagation in gaseous media varies from multi-kilometer propagation paths in the atmosphere using multi-terawatt (TW) pulsed laser sources to short few centimeter path propagation in high pressure (multi-atmosphere) capillaries whereby higher harmonic cascades beyond the 5,000-th harmonic of a fundamental generate coherent soft X-ray pulses. The former are being employed to detect atmospheric pollutants and molecular species at ranges up to 30 kilometers in the upper atmosphere and are exhibiting the potential to detect chemical and biological warfare agents. Further societal impacts of new discoveries in this emerging field include: direct observation of the ultrafast motions of the electrons controlling the molecules of life, the dynamics of proteins or the motion of atoms in semiconductors and compact sources of intense particle beams for physics research and medical applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Filamentation nonlinear optics is an emerging multidisciplinary area of nonlinear science that has the potential to have an enormous impact across a broad swath of commercial and military applications. A light filament is a superintense, very small diameter (around 100 µm) light channel that forms over a finite distance from an initially much wider laser beam. This happens explosively and can be associated with what is called the “blow-up” singularity of a very famous equation, the Nonlinear Schroedinger equation. Understanding the extreme events associated with explosive filament formation requires a deep knowledge of advanced mathematics, theoretical and experimental physics. The goal of the international workshop on  “MATHEMATICAL METHODS AND MODELS IN LASER FILAMENTATION” hosted by the Centre de Recherches Mathematiques (CRM) at the University of Montreal from March 10-14, 2014 was to bring together leading world experts from mathematics, theoretical and experimental physics in this field in a focused pedagogical setting amenable to educating an emerging generation of young scientists. Young U.S researchers had an opportunity to present poster presentations of their own work and engage in one-on-one discussions with the workshop speakers.

 

Since its first observation in a laboratory in the mid 90’s, the field has grown exponentially over the past decade. A key breakthrough in 1997 by a group at the University of Jena, Germany led to the establishment of a joint Franco-German project named Teramobile. The latter refers to a mobile laser platform capable of delivering multiple Terawatt power femtosecond duration laser pulses over  multiple kilometer distances. This platform was employed as a femtosecond LIDAR system that could detect molecular species at elevations of 30 kilometers and beyond vertically in the atmosphere. The key physics employed in this application exploits a white light spectrum generated by the superintense filament that can be used as a remote flashlamp for remote spectroscopy. Multiple possible applications spin-offs rapidly followed. The remote flashlamp can be used to detect pollutants and possibly, chemical and biological agents at remote locations. The light intensity in the filament is so high that it ionizes the constituents of air (N2, O2, Argon, water etc) to create an extended plasma channel – the latter is analogous to a conducting wire which has been proposed to aid in diverting lightning strikes from sensitive equipment such as power stations.  Furthermore filaments created in high pressure (multi-atmosphere) capillaries containing inert gases can produce up to the 5,000-th harmonic of a fundamental laser pulse and produce coherent soft X-ray pulses. The latter can be employed to probe ultrafast motion of individual atoms in solids for example.
